urn:contentItem:6CSS-Y1K1-DY7R-R010-00000-00Oregon State University Researcher Highlights Research in Forestry (Enhancing Forest Fire Communication: A Case Study of Oregon Government Social Media)2024-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:15:20ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - FORESTRYOregon State University Researcher Highlights Research in Forestry (Enhancing Forest Fire Communication: A Case Study of Oregon Government Social Media)


2024 AUG 22 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- New study results on forestry have been published. According to news reporting originating from Oregon State University by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires pose an escalating threat, demanding effective communication strategies for communities."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Oregon State University: "While past research underscores the importance of community involvement and transparent communication, the dominance of social media in today's media landscape calls for a reassessment. This study investigates the utilization of social media, specifically Facebook, by the Oregon government during the 2022 fire season in Cedar Creek and Double Creek regions. Through Facepager, 4576 posts and comments were collected and then analyzed using the multi-coder approach and Vader Algorithm focusing on post frequency, thematic content, and user sentiments. The result reveals that positive sentiment polarity scores were observed with 0.61 and 0.71 for Cedar Creek and Double Creek respectively, however, the thematic and post-frequency analysis suggests a need for government agencies to diversify content, emphasizing scientific aspects and addressing community concerns."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The findings offer valuable insights for enhancing risk communication strategies, promoting informed public engagement, and guiding effective government communication in wildfire scenarios."
For more information on this research see: Enhancing Forest Fire Communication: A Case Study of Oregon Government Social Media. Jurnal Manajemen Hutan Tropika, 2024,30(2). Dad's Garage celebrates 30 years with special weekend events

Image via Dad's Garage website.

Dad's Garage Theatre is marking its 30th anniversary with a series of events from July 24 to 26.

The celebration starts with a free showcase featuring improv students and conservatory members. On Friday, the theatre will present a special edition of TheatreSports, a long-running improv competition featuring current and former performers. The weekend concludes with an improv jam on Saturday, followed by a birthday party for attendees to connect with the theatre community.

Dad's Garage co-artistic director Jon Carr noted that the events are a way to recognize the theatre's history and supporters since its founding. The theatre began in a warehouse in the Old Fourth Ward and has grown to become a notable comedy venue in the Southeast.

Tickets are available here.

— Derek Prall

Pruzhansky, Chinn win Atlanta Opera's 96-Hour Festival with #8216;Rose, Tree'

Librettist Hai-Ting Chinn and composer Dina Pruzhansky are awarded the top prize in The Atlanta Opera's 96-Hour Opera Festival 2025.

Composer Dina Pruzhansky and librettist Hai-Ting Chinn won the 2025 96-Hour Opera Festival, hosted by The Atlanta Opera, with their moving work #8216;Rose, Tree (Rosenbaum and Li).#8217; The 10-minute opera scene, set in 1967, tells the story of two mothers — a Holocaust survivor and a Chinese American woman — whose children are in an interracial relationship.

The piece was performed live June 21 at the Ray Charles Performing Arts Center at Morehouse College. Pruzhansky and Chinn will share a $10,000 prize and receive a commission to expand the scene into a full chamber opera.

The festival featured five new works developed over four days. #8216;TransBliss#8217; by Rebecca and Rachel Gray was named runner-up, while #8216;Desert Bloom#8217; by Gillian Rae Perry and Mo Holmes won Audience Favorite.

The event also included the world premiere of #8216;Steele Roots,#8217; developed by last year's winners, and was held in partnership with Morehouse College.

— Derek Prall

Road closures, new expo location announced for 2025 Peachtree Road Race

The Atlanta Track Club has released road closure and traffic plans ahead of the 56th running of the AJC Peachtree Road Race, taking place July 4. Tens of thousands are expected to take part in the multi-day event, with rolling street closures beginning as early as July 2.

A major change for 2025 includes the debut of the Peachtree Health & Fitness Expo at Lenox Square, moving from the Georgia World Congress Center. The new location puts the event in a walkable area with nearby dining, shopping and hotels.

Road closures begin at 12 a.m. July 2, with Peachtree Road closed between Lenox Parkway and Lenox Road. Additional closures are planned July 3 and 4.

Atlanta Police Department will assist with traffic management throughout the area. Event maps and a full list of closures are available on the Atlanta Track Club website.

— Derek Prall

Trust for Public Land acquires more than 21 acres at Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield

Image via the Trust for Public Land website.

Trust for Public Land has closed on the acquisition of 21.467 acres at Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park, a key Civil War site in the Southeast. The addition protects the land from residential development and preserves it for public use, historical education and conservation.

The property is now owned by the National Park Service. It maintains the area's rural character and safeguards potential Civil War archaeological resources. The site includes a pond used during a March 2025 forest fire for helicopter water drops.

#8216;In partnership with the National Park Service, we're proud to protect this historic land for future generations,#8217; said George Dusenbury, Georgia state director for Trust for Public Land.

Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield now covers 2,923 acres with 18 miles of trails. Past acquisitions by Trust for Public Land helped expand and preserve the park since the early 2000s.

— Derek Prall

Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation awards $10 million grant to First Tee

Image via First Tee website.

The Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation has awarded a $10 million grant to First Tee, reinforcing its long-standing partnership with the youth golf development organization. Since 1999, the foundation has contributed more than $25 million to First Tee.

The grant supports First Tee's mission to expand access to golf and its character-building programs, which reach more than 3 million youth annually. The funding will strengthen curriculum for teenagers and provide grants to local First Tee chapters in PGA TOUR Superstore markets.

Arthur M. Blank, owner and chairman of the foundation and PGA TOUR Superstore, praised the organization's impact on youth confidence and leadership skills. The grant also supports the Leadership Series and Leadership Summit programs for teens.

The foundation and First Tee celebrated the grant with a weeklong leadership event for 48 First Tee teens in Atlanta, featuring visits to PGA TOUR Superstore and sports facilities.

First Tee combines golf instruction with life skills training for youth ages 7 to 18. More information can be found here.

— Derek Prall

Blue Heron's wellness series to return this August with free outdoor events

Blue Heron Nature Preserve's annual Health and Wellness Month returns this August for its fifth season, offering free outdoor wellness programs each Saturday.

Local experts will lead these guided sessions within Blue Heron's 30-acre urban greenspace. All events are held outdoors, and advance registration is recommended as workshops may fill quickly. RSVP and learn more here.

Schedule of events:

Aug. 2: Morning Yoga in the Woodlands

Start your month with a breath-centered yoga session in the forest. Slow down and attune to the rhythms of nature in this gentle, grounding practice.

Aug. 9: Birds of Blue Heron: A Guided Walk

A guided nature walk that invites you to observe your surroundings with clarity and calm. Discover and learn about local birds while practicing mindfulness.

Aug. 16: Healing Sounds in Nature

Immerse yourself in the healing sounds of singing bowls and calming frequencies during this restorative outdoor sound healing session.

Aug. 23: Herbs and Healing Plants: A Guided Walk

Stroll the Preserve with an experienced herbalist and learn to identify wild plants with traditional uses. Sample wild snacks and herbal teas along the way.

— Megan Anderson

H.O.P.E. Inc. named finalist for Nonprofit Leader Award

H.O.P.E. Inc., a Duluth nonprofit dedicated to empowering single parents to achieve educational and economic goals, is a finalist for the 2025 Bill Bolling Nonprofit Leader Award, part of the annual TechBridge Award Series.

Presented by TechBridge, an Atlanta-based nonprofit that supports other nonprofits with technology and data strategies, the award honors organizations demonstrating visionary leadership, innovation, and measurable impact advancing economic mobility for underrepresented communities.

The award is named after Bill Bolling, founder of the Atlanta Community Food Bank and longtime equity advocate. It recognizes servant leadership and bold action toward systemic change.

#8216;We are honored to be recognized among the finalists for this prestigious award,#8217; said H.O.P.E. CEO Kenita Smith. #8216;This nomination underscores the incredible progress our team and the families we serve are making every day.#8217;

The 2025 award event will take place in Atlanta later this year.

— Derek Prall

Monday Night Brewing expands with #8216;The Grove#8216;

Monday Night Brewing is expanding its West Midtown location with a new indoor-outdoor space called The Grove, opening in August. The Grove, located at 670 Trabert Ave., sits adjacent to the current taproom and directly on a new section of the Atlanta Beltline Northwest Trail.

The expansion includes a 7,400-square-foot taproom, 17,000 square feet of outdoor space with fire pits, and an amphitheater for live music. It will offer 30 taps featuring seasonal and exclusive beers, house-made pizzas, coffee and breakfast options.

Joel Iverson, co-founder, said The Grove will be a place to connect with friends and enjoy fresh beer and good vibes. The existing taproom will remain open for events and production.

The new Beltline segment connects Northside Drive and Howell Mill Road, enhancing access to The Grove.

A hiring fair is planned for July. Click here for more information.

— Derek Prall

Howard University Alumni Club of Atlanta honored with heartsaver hero award

Left to right: Amber Taylor, Erin Thomas and Erin White with AED and Awards.

The American Heart Association awarded the Heartsaver Hero Award to the Howard University Alumni Club of Atlanta and Amber Taylor for their response to a cardiac emergency at Westside Park.

In June 2024, Howard graduate A. Binford Carter suffered sudden cardiac arrest at the MEAC Nation Cookout. Club members and others performed CPR for 30 minutes until EMS arrived. Carter later died at the hospital.

In his memory, the club helped donate three automated external defibrillators to Westside Park. The club also formed a Health & Wellness Committee to provide CPR training and promote heart health awareness.

Erin White, club president, said, #8216;This award reminds us how powerful community can be when we come together.#8217;

The American Heart Association urges everyone to learn CPR to save lives. More information is available here.

— Derek Prall

Norfolk Southern awards over 100 scholarships to railroaders' children

Norfolk Southern's 2025 Thoroughbred Scholars program awarded 100 scholarships of up to $10,000 and three special scholarships of up to $40,000 to high school seniors and college students demonstrating academic excellence, leadership, and community service.

President and CEO Mark George said, #8216;Building a better future begins with empowering the next generation.#8217;

The three special scholarships went to Chandler Hoffman (STEM), Zion Fennell (HBCU), and Maggie Purgason (Community).

Since 2022, the program has awarded $4.48 million across 22 states. Click here to learn more.

— Derek Prall

CHRIS 180 adds eight new board members, announces leadership team

CHRIS 180, a nonprofit supporting the mental health of children, youth and families, has appointed eight new members to its board of directors and announced its elected board officers.

New board members bring expertise in finance, education, law, healthcare and corporate leadership:

Mike Knox, senior vice president at PNC Bank

Nicole Long, vice president of finance at Agnes Scott College

Dawn Rhoden, senior vice president at Bank of America

Christine T. St.Clare, retired KPMG board member and audit partner

David Tetrick, partner at King & Spalding and incoming global chief human resources officer

Vasanne Tinsley, former interim superintendent of DeKalb County Schools

Board officers include Lori B. Chennault of Georgia-Pacific as chair, Deirdra Glover of Conserte Consulting as vice chair, Ana Amato of Protiviti as treasurer, and community volunteer Erika Montag as secretary.

President and CEO Cati Diamond Stone said the leadership team will help deepen the organization's impact.

— Derek Prall

Purpose Built SchoolsAtlanta welcomes three new board members

Purpose Built SchoolsAtlanta has appointed Joshua Barber, Brittany Collins and Shannon Judd to its board of directors, strengthening its commitment to building thriving neighborhood schools.

Barber, president of the South Atlanta Civic League, brings more than 20 years of community leadership experience in Historic South Atlanta. Collins, executive director of the Betty and Davis Fitzgerald Foundation, has led efforts to expand education and mental health access across Georgia. Judd, president of Integral Property Management, oversees a national real estate portfolio and offers expertise in affordable housing and operations.

#8216;We are thrilled to welcome Joshua, Brittany and Shannon to our board,#8217; said Mike Davis, CEO of Purpose Built SchoolsAtlanta. #8216;Their diverse experiences and shared commitment to equitable education and community transformation will be critical as we continue our mission.#8217;

Purpose Built SchoolsAtlanta partners with Atlanta Public Schools to operate three neighborhood schools in south Atlanta.

— Derek Prall

SEEA names new executive director

The Southeast Energy Efficiency Alliance has appointed John Silkey as its new executive director, effective July 7.

Silkey brings more than a decade of experience in clean energy, sustainability and organizational development. He previously chaired SEEA's board and was principal at Headwaters Services, guiding clients on strategic planning and culture alignment.

#8216;We are thrilled to welcome John to SEEA,#8217; said Lauren Casentini, chair of SEEA's board. #8216;His knowledge, passion for equitable solutions and collaborative style make him the ideal leader.#8217;

Silkey will relocate to Atlanta in August. He said energy efficiency remains #8216;the lowest cost and most accessible tool#8217; for addressing climate challenges and energy burden in the Southeast.

Silkey succeeds Aimee Skrzekut, who resigned in January after leading SEEA since 2021. Casentini praised Skrzekut's impact and looked forward to the organization's future.

— Derek Prall

Christian City invests in key leadership hires to accelerate growth

Christian City, a 60-year-old nonprofit with a 500-acre campus near Atlanta, announced two key leadership hires: Mark Sexton as Chief Operating Officer and Chaundra Luckett as Executive Director of Marketing and Communications.

President and CEO Keith Horton said their expertise will deepen Christian City's mission. Sexton, a retired U.S. Army officer with 30 years of experience and personal ties to the organization, will oversee day-to-day operations and lead expansions in senior living, the THRIVE program, and the Graceland thrift store revitalization. These hires come as Christian City embarks on a year of growth and transformation.

#8216;For generations, Christian City has been a beacon of hope, so I'm honored to join the team and further advance this crucial work,#8217; said Sexton. #8216;Having grown up connected to this community through my family, I have an intimate understanding of the mission at hand and the impact it has on residents' lives. I look forward to working alongside Horton and the entire team to continue to expand Christian City's reach.#8217;

— Derek Prall

Young innovators showcased technological solutionsfor environmental protection

The “Sustainable Development” hackathon co-organized by Azercell
and Eventify took place at Oxbridge Academy on January 18, 2025.
The initiative aimed to unlock the innovative potential of the
young people, while fostering the development of environmentally
focused technologies, and advancing the startup ecosystem in
Azerbaijan.

The competition brought together 11 teams of young participants
aged between 12 and 18 years old. Over six hours, the teams worked
on technological challenges addressing issues of environmental
protection. Guided by experienced mentors, the young innovators
developed prototypes of their concepts and presented their
solutions to a panel of judges.

The "Bono" team secured first place with a project, which
promotes environmental engagement through a point-based reward
system. The second place was awarded to the "Homeboys" team for
their sustainable city initiative, while the "JoshuaTech" team
earned third place for their proposal to leverage drones for forest
fire prevention.

The winning teams were rewarded with prizes and special gifts
from Azercell.

For more information about “Azercell Telecom” LLC and its
activities, please visit the official Azercell
website.

urn:contentItem:6BH0-1F91-DY7R-R1RD-00000-00Data on Forest Ecosystems Described by Researchers at Nanjing Forestry University (Reconstructing historical forest fire risk in the non-satellite era using the improved forest fire danger index and long short-term memory deep learning-a case ...)2024-03-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:15:20ZLexisNexisECOLOGY - FOREST ECOSYSTEMSData on Forest Ecosystems Described by Researchers at Nanjing Forestry University (Reconstructing historical forest fire risk in the non-satellite era using the improved forest fire danger index and long short-term memory deep learning-a case ...)


2024 MAR 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Research findings on forest ecosystems are discussed in a new report. According to news originating from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Historical forest fire risk databases are vital for evaluating the effectiveness of past forest management approaches, enhancing forest fire warnings and emergency response capabilities, and accurately budgeting potential carbon emissions resulting from fires. However, due to the unavailability of spatial information technology, such databases are extremely difficult to build reliably and completely in the non-satellite era."


Financial supporters for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "This study presented an improved forest fire risk reconstruction framework that integrates a deep learning-based time series prediction model and spatial interpolation to address the challenge in Sichuan Province, southwestern China. First, the forest fire danger index (FFDI) was improved by supplementing slope and aspect information. We compared the performances of three time series models, namely, the autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA), Prophet and long short-term memory (LSTM) in predicting the modified forest fire danger index (MFFDI). The best-performing model was used to retrace the MFFDI of individual stations from 1941 to 1970. Following this, the Anusplin spatial interpolation method was used to map the distributions of the MFFDI at five-year intervals, which were then subjected to weighted overlay with the distance-to-river layer to generate forest fire risk maps for reconstructing the forest fire danger database. The results revealed LSTM as the most accurate in fitting and predicting the historical MFFDI, with a fitting determination coefficient (R2) of 0.709, mean square error (MSE) of 0.047, and validation R2 and MSE of 0.508 and 0.11, respectively."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Independent validation of the predicted forest fire risk maps indicated that 5 out of 7 historical forest fire events were located in forest fire-prone areas, which is higher than the results determined from the original FFDI (2 out of 7). This proves the effectiveness of the improved MFFDI and indicates a high level of reliability of the historical forest fire risk reconstruction method proposed in this study."
For more information on this research see: Reconstructing historical forest fire risk in the non-satellite era using the improved forest fire danger index and long short-term memory deep learning-a case study in Sichuan Province, southwestern China. Forest Ecosystems, 2024,11():100170. (Forest Ecosystems - http://www.forestecosyst.com/). The publisher for Forest Ecosystems is KeAi Communications Co., Ltd.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fecs.2024.100170.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Yuwen Peng, Co-Innovation Center for Sustainable Forestry in Southern China, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Huiyi Su, Min Sun, Mingshi Li.

urn:contentItem:6BXG-82T1-DY7R-R03M-00000-00Reports Outline Natural Hazards Research Study Results from Assam University (Forest fire in Thailand: Spatio-temporal distribution and future risk assessment)2024-04-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:15:20ZLexisNexisNATURAL HAZARDS RESEARCHReports Outline Natural Hazards Research Study Results from Assam University (Forest fire in Thailand: Spatio-temporal distribution and future risk assessment)


2024 APR 30 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Research findings on natural hazards research are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting from Silchar, India, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Understanding the spatiotemporal distribution of forest fires and future predictions is very important for management strategies."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Assam University: "To identify the present status of forest fires in the Kingdom of Thailand and their risk in the future, ten-year forest fire data were used, and a forest fire hotspot was prepared. A geospatial technique was used in the study to characterize the parameters of forest fires in the country and identify future forest fire risk areas. Most of the forest fires in the country were found to be seasonal. Deciduous forests in higher elevations and on moderate slopes were most vulnerable to forest fire. The level of aridity, soil moisture, temperature, precipitation, vegetation status, and topography influenced the spatiotemporal distribution of forest fires in the country. Greater than 50% of fire risks were observed in 22 administrative divisions, and 17 of the 209 protected areas are also in the high-risk category."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The final forest fire hotspot map can be used in policy development and successful management strategies. A better monitoring strategy should be used in the fire hotspot areas as a precautionary measure to minimize the anthropogenic causes of forest fires."
For more information on this research see: Forest fire in Thailand: Spatio-temporal distribution and future risk assessment. Natural Hazards Research, 2024,4(1):87-96. The publisher for Natural Hazards Research is KeAi Communications Co. Ltd.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nhres.2023.09.002.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Nazimur Rahman Talukdar, Wildlife Conservation Research Unit, Department of Ecology and Environmental Sciences, Assam University, Silchar, 788011, India. Additional authors for this research include Firoz Ahmad, Laxmi Goparaju, Parthankar Choudhury, Abdul Qayum, Javed Rizvi.

Publisher’s noteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

UAV-based aerial imagery plays a vital role in detecting surface cracks in mining-induced areas for geological disaster early warning and safe production. However, detection is challenged by small crack size, complex morphology, large scale variation, and uneven spatial distribution, further exacerbated by UAVs’ limited onboard computational capacity. To tackle these issues, we introduce an efficient and lightweight small-target detection model, namely YOLO-LSN, which is built upon the optimized YOLO architecture.Firstly, we introduce a Lightweight Dynamic Alignment Detection Head (LDADH) for multi-scale feature fusion, precise alignment, and dynamic receptive field adjustment, optimizing crack feature extraction. Secondly, the Small Object Feature Enhancement Pyramid (SOFEP) enhances detail representation of small cracks in complex backgrounds.Furthermore, we propose a weighted combination strategy of Normalized Wasserstein Distance (NWD) and IoU loss, balancing sensitivity to zero-overlap instances and robustness against scale deviations, thereby improving localization accuracy and generalization capability. Experiments show a 12% mAP@0.5 improvement and 17% reduction in parameters on a self-built mining crack dataset, with further validation on VisDrone2019 (mAP@0.5: 0.422, + 11.6%), Validating its effectiveness for UAV-based small-object detection, the model offers an efficient, reliable solution for geological hazard warning and mining safety.

IntroductionThe continuous expansion of mining activities has made mining-induced surface cracks one of the significant geological phenomena affecting the safety of mining operations. Surface cracks not only compromise the stability of the mining area’s environment but may also trigger severe geological hazards, such as subsidence.

and landslides, which pose substantial risks to surrounding infrastructure and the safety of local populations. Additionally, surface subsidence and cracks can lead to structural damage and collapse of surface buildings, resulting in economic losses. They may also induce spontaneous combustion of residual coal in mined-out areas, leading to coalfield fires1, 2, 3, 4, 5–6. Therefore, the rapid and accurate detection of mining-induced surface cracks is of paramount importance for understanding the movement patterns of overlying strata, ensuring the safe production of coal mines, and implementing comprehensive environmental management in mining areas.

Traditional methods for detecting mining-induced surface cracks, such as manual visual inspections, ground-based observations, and remote sensing image analysis, face several challenges, including low detection efficiency, high labor costs, and the inability to meet the demands of large-scale real-time monitoring5. Manual visual inspection is not only time-consuming and labor-intensive but also difficult to implement in complex terrains or adverse weather conditions, with the results being highly susceptible to subjective factors. While ground-based observations offer higher accuracy, they are limited to small, key areas and cannot cover the entire mining influence zone, with the added disadvantage of high equipment deployment costs7. Remote sensing image analysis, although capable of large-scale monitoring, is constrained by image resolution, revisit cycles, and weather conditions, making it difficult to capture dynamic changes in cracks in real-time8. Furthermore, traditional methods face significant challenges in data integration and analysis, making it difficult to achieve automated processing and intelligent analysis of multi-source data9. With the expansion of mining activities and the increasing demands for environmental protection and safety, there is an urgent need to introduce efficient, precise, and intelligent monitoring technologies, such as UAV-based remote sensing and deep learning-based image recognition methods, to enhance the automation and real-time monitoring capabilities of surface crack detection.

In recent years, with the rapid development of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) technology, UAV-based aerial imagery for surface crack monitoring has gradually become an effective alternative. UAVs can efficiently capture high-resolution surface images and cover large monitoring areas, providing rich data support for surface crack detection in mining areas. Zhang et al. (2022)10 employed UAV photogrammetry and particle flow theory to analyze the surface crack characteristics of the 8092 work face in a coal mine in Ordos. The study found that the visual interpretation method based on UAV images achieved a crack recognition accuracy of 95%, and elucidated the distribution patterns and formation mechanisms of the cracks. However, the UAV images used in this study had a ground resolution of 5.6 cm/pixel, which made it difficult to detect tiny cracks. Additionally, the photogrammetric process is prone to interference from weather conditions, lighting changes, vegetation cover, and terrain undulations, potentially leading to degraded image quality and, consequently, reduced crack recognition accuracy. Although UAV aerial photography provides an efficient means of data acquisition for surface crack monitoring, due to limitations in flight altitude and resolution, cracks that may extend for tens of meters on a macro scale often appear as thin, discontinuous linear features in aerial images, with widths occupying only a few pixels, representing a typical small-object detection problem. Furthermore, these cracks exhibit characteristics such as low contrast, complex shapes, and significant scale differences, and are often obscured by complex backgrounds or surface features like rocks, further complicating the detection process.

Existing object detection algorithms, particularly those based on deep learning, such as the YOLO series11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18–19, although demonstrating excellent performance in most object detection tasks, still face challenges in detecting small targets like tiny cracks in complex backgrounds. This is due to insufficient feature extraction, leading to issues such as missed or false detections. Zhong (2024)20 et al. proposed SPD-YOLOv8, a small-object detection algorithm for UAV images in complex scenes. This method introduces the SPD-Conv module, replacing traditional strided convolutions and pooling operations in YOLOv8s, thereby enhancing the retention of small-object features. It also reconstructs the feature extraction and fusion network, incorporating a small-object detection layer and MPDIoU loss function, which improves detection accuracy. However, the introduction of the small-object detection layer results in a model that is still not lightweight, with high computational overhead, making it difficult to meet the deployment requirements for edge devices. Furthermore, its ability to fuse multi-scale features in complex backgrounds is limited, and it struggles with adapting to targets that exhibit large scale variations or severe occlusions. Additionally, traditional YOLO models typically use non-maximum suppression (NMS) for post-processing, leading to some inference delays, which limits their application on UAVs and other mobile devices. Therefore, we chose YOLOv10, a real-time end-to-end object detection model proposed by a research team from Tsinghua University21, as our baseline in the YOLO series. This model employs a consistent dual-assignment strategy, avoiding the need for NMS to eliminate duplicate prediction boxes during inference, significantly reducing post-processing time. It achieves the fastest inference speed while maintaining detection accuracy comparable to other models in the same category.

To address the challenges of detecting small targets such as complex crack shapes, significant scale differences, and the need for model lightweighting in mining-induced surface crack detection, we propose the YOLO-LSN model, an efficient and lightweight solution for small-object detection. This model enhances multi-scale feature fusion and reduces the number of parameters through the innovative Lightweight Dynamic Alignment Detection Head (LDADH). The LDADH leverages a shared convolution module and replaces traditional batch normalization (BN)23 with Group Normalization (GN)22 for stable training with small batch sizes. To further improve detection performance, we incorporate a Task Decoupling Module and dynamic alignment mechanism, along with DCNV224 deformable convolution and Scale25 layers to enhance the model’s adaptability to various crack scales and shapes.In addition, we propose a Small Object Feature Enhancement Pyramid (SOFEP) that enhances fine-grained feature capture. The P2 feature layer is processed with the SPD-Conv26 module to generate features rich in small-object information, which are then fused with the P3 layer, boosted by the CSP-OmniKernel module for improved feature representation and sensitivity to cracks.Furthermore, we introduce a weighted combination of the NWD27 regression loss and the IoU28 loss functions to address the gradient vanishing issue of IoU in zero-overlap cases and its insensitivity to target size deviations, thereby optimizing small target localization accuracy.

The main contributions of this paper are as follows:

Propose a Lightweight Dynamic Alignment Detection Head (LDADH) for multi-scale feature fusion and model lightweighting.

Introduce a Small Object Feature Enhancement Pyramid (SOFEP) to improve fine-grained small-object feature capture.

Employ a weighted combination of NWD and IoU loss functions for enhanced small target localization accuracy.

We have constructed a mining-induced surface crack image dataset, which covers various complex terrains and crack targets of different shapes. Small targets (less than 32 × 32 pixels) account for 96.06% of the dataset, filling the data gap in small-scale crack detection in high-resolution aerial imagery.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows: Sect. 2 introduces related work on crack detection, and Sect. 3 provides a detailed description of the proposed YOLO-LSN architecture. Section 4 presents the experimental details, with a comparison of the proposed method’s performance against several benchmark models, validating the robustness and lightweight nature of YOLO-LSN. Section 5 concludes the paper and outlines directions for future research.

Related works

Recent progress and research trends in crack detection techniques

In recent years, with the rapid development of computer vision and deep learning technologies, UAV-based and image processing methods for crack detection have gradually become a research hotspot. Particularly in the field of mining-induced surface crack detection, challenges such as complex crack shapes, background interference, and small target sizes have imposed higher demands on detection algorithms.

To improve the adaptability to the complexity of crack shapes, Wang et al. (2024)29 proposed a crack detection method based on an anchor-free framework. By analyzing the texture features of cracks and contextual information, they optimized the YOLOX-x algorithm and introduced a semantic enhancement module to improve the recognition ability for elongated cracks. Although the anchor-free design reduces the dependence on hyperparameters, the method may suffer from false detections or missed detections in scenarios with dense or intersecting cracks, and it has limited capability in detecting the continuity of extremely elongated cracks.

For crack detection in complex backgrounds, Dang et al. (2024)30 proposed a UAV-based road crack detection algorithm, RCYOLO. This algorithm extracts tubular crack features by introducing the C2f_DSConv module and combines the SimAM attention mechanism31 with the dyhead detection head32, effectively addressing the issue of missed detections for small targets. Experimental results show that RCYOLO improves mAP@0.5 by 5.9% over YOLOv8 on a custom dataset, providing a valuable technical reference for crack detection in complex backgrounds. Additionally, Wang et al. (2024)33 proposed a computer vision-based intelligent crack detection and classification model. By improving the detection layer, anchor boxes, neck structure, and cross-layer connections of YOLOv5, the model achieves certain improvements in crack detection performance. However, its adaptability to multi-scale cracks is limited, especially in detecting small cracks (less than 32 × 32 pixels), where detection accuracy still needs improvement. Tang et al. (2024)34 proposed an improved YOLOv5s algorithm, which enhances crack detection accuracy under complex road conditions by re-clustering anchor points using the k-means + + algorithm, and incorporating the CBAM attention module35 and the CIoU_Loss loss function36. Although the optimization of anchor boxes and the loss function improved detection, it does not account for the impact of dynamic environments on detection.

In the optimization of multi-scale crack detection algorithms, Zhang et al. (2024)37 proposed a multi-scale crack detection algorithm based on USSC-YOLO. By introducing ShuffleNet V238, the Coordinate Attention mechanism (CA)39, and the Swin Transformer module40, the algorithm significantly reduces computational overhead and improves the detection accuracy of small target cracks. Experimental results show that the algorithm improves mAP@50 and mAP@[50:95] by 6.3% and 12%, respectively. However, its real-time performance is average, making it difficult to meet the needs of UAV high-speed inspections, and its robustness for crack detection under non-uniform lighting conditions is insufficient. Xue et al. (2024)41 proposed a lightweight Mini-YOLOv5s algorithm, which reduces model computational complexity and parameters by introducing the DP-C3 module, GDConv module42, ECA-C3 module, and CARAFE upsampling operator43. However, the excessive compression of parameters leads to a decline in the model’s generalization ability for complex crack shapes (e.g., branching cracks). Furthermore, Zhou et al. (2024)44 proposed an improved wood crack detection algorithm based on YOLOv8, ICDW-YOLO. By incorporating a dual-layer attention mechanism and dynamic gradient enhancement features, it enhances the detection capability for small target cracks, achieving an mAP50-95 of 79.018%. However, the algorithm struggles with suppressing interference from complex backgrounds, potentially leading to false recognition of non-crack structures.

Performance limitations of existing crack detection models and research motivation

A review of the existing literature reveals that most current studies focus on optimizing isolated components of model structures, while lacking an effective synergy among detection accuracy, lightweight design, and adaptability to complex scenarios. The specific limitations are summarized as follows:

Wang et al. (2024) proposed an anchor-free improved YOLOX algorithm, which performs well in detecting elongated cracks. However, it suffers from false positives and missed detections in scenes with dense or intersecting cracks. Tang et al. enhanced the YOLOv5s architecture by incorporating CBAM and CIoU_Loss, achieving improved precision in static pavement detection. Nevertheless, the method still lacks sufficient generalization capability in dynamic or complex conditions.

Modules such as SimAM, CBAM, and Coordinate Attention (CA) have been widely adopted to enhance the saliency of crack features. Dang et al. combined SimAM with DyHead, significantly improving small object detection performance. Zhou et al. designed a dual-layer attention structure to enhance the detection capability of YOLOv8. However, most of these approaches do not adequately consider the trade-off between the computational overhead introduced by attention mechanisms and the real-time performance required in practical scenarios.

Zhang et al. introduced USSC-YOLO by integrating ShuffleNet V2 and Transformer modules, which achieved promising detection accuracy. However, its real-time performance was compromised due to the increased computational complexity. Xue et al. proposed Mini-YOLOv5s, utilizing modules such as DP-C3 and GDConv to significantly compress model size. Nevertheless, the model’s ability to recognize complex crack patterns declined as a result.

Many algorithms still face challenges in maintaining stable performance under adverse conditions, such as drastic illumination changes, occlusion, or complex background textures. For example, ICDW-YOLO performed well in detecting wood cracks but lacked robustness in suppressing pseudo-cracks. RCYOLO incorporated both feature extraction and attention mechanisms, yet it did not address scale adaptivity or robustness against motion blur.

In summary, while existing methods have achieved breakthroughs in specific performance dimensions, they often face trade-offs in others—particularly struggling to simultaneously ensure high accuracy for small object detection, robustness in complex environments, and real-time efficiency. To address these challenges, the YOLO-LSN model proposed in this paper is designed to overcome the limitations of conventional approaches by striving for an effective balance among detection accuracy, model lightweightness, and adaptability to diverse mining-induced crack scenarios, thereby enhancing the overall practical performance of crack detection systems.

Proposed alogorithm

YOLO-LSN network overview

As shown in Fig. 1, YOLOv10 is an end-to-end real-time object detection model proposed by the Tsinghua University team in 2024. It aims to address the excessive reliance of the YOLO series on Non-Maximum Suppression (NMS), thereby achieving more efficient inference performance. Its overall architecture follows the classical three-stage design of Backbone–Neck–Head. The backbone network consists of several key modules, including the Conv module, SCDown module, C2f module, C2f-CIB module, and the PSA self-attention mechanism, enabling efficient feature extraction and multi-scale information fusion. The neck adopts an FPN-PAN structure to integrate multi-scale features from the backbone. In the detection head, a lightweight decoupled design is employed, combined with a dual-assignment strategy, which effectively alleviates the performance bottleneck caused by overdependence on NMS in traditional YOLO models.

Based on the YOLOv10 architecture, we propose an improved model named YOLO-LSN (YOLO-Lightweight Structure for NWD). While maintaining the advantages of efficiency and an end-to-end structure, YOLO-LSN introduces three key enhancements targeting small object detection and crack recognition tasks:

In the backbone, YOLO-LSN inherits the structure of YOLOv10, fully retaining the C2f module and the multi-scale feature extraction path to ensure sufficient feature representation capability.

In the neck, we introduce the SPD-Conv module to enhance the P2 feature layer, improving the representation of small object features. The processed features are then fused with the P3 layer and further enhanced by the CSP-OmniKernel module, which strengthens the model’s sensitivity to fine-grained crack features.

In the head, a Lightweight Dynamic Alignment Detection Head (LDADH) is designed to improve adaptability to cracks of varying scales and shapes, while significantly reducing model complexity to meet lightweight deployment requirements.

Additionally, we incorporate a loss function based on the Normalized Wasserstein Distance (NWD), which is more suitable for small object detection and effectively improves the localization accuracy for tiny targets.

Lightweight dynamic alignment detection head (LDADH)

Fig. 2

Structure Diagram of Lightweight Dynamic Alignment Detection Head (LDADH).

To address the challenges in mining-induced surface crack detection, such as complex crack shapes, significant scale differences, and the need for model lightweighting, we propose a Lightweight Dynamic Aligned Detection Head (LDADH), as shown in Fig. 2. The LDADH first employs a Shared Convolution module for multi-scale feature fusion. This module consists of two convolution layers with Group Normalization (GN) stacked together, achieving multi-level information fusion through feature concatenation, significantly reducing the model’s parameter size. Traditional YOLO detection head convolution layers typically use Batch Normalization (BN). However, BN performs well in large-batch training but has limited effectiveness in small-batch scenarios, especially when high-resolution mining-induced surface crack images are used as input. Therefore, we replace BN with GN, where GN divides the feature channels into multiple groups (in this paper, Num_Groups = 16), and normalizes the mean and standard deviation independently within each group. As shown in Fig. 3, the case for Num_Groups = 3 is illustrated. The statistics in GN depend only on the group-wise channels and spatial dimensions of the current sample, eliminating the dependency on batch size, thereby maintaining stability during small-batch or single-sample training. Additionally, GN retains local dependencies between channels through the grouping strategy, enhancing the model’s ability to capture fine-grained features.The core computational steps are as follows:

Grouping: The channel dimension C is divided into G groups, with each group containing C/G channels.

Statistics Calculation: For each group, the mean and standard deviation are calculated along the spatial dimensions (H, W) and within the channels of the group.

The input features then pass through the Task Decoupling Module, which decomposes the input features into independent classification branches (ClsFeat) and regression branches (RegFeat) using a dynamic weight adjustment mechanism, in order to optimize object classification confidence and localization accuracy, respectively. Specifically, the input features are first processed by global average pooling45 to extract global context information. Then, they pass through two convolutional layers (La_conv1 and La_conv2) and nonlinear activation functions (ReLU and Sigmoid) to generate dynamic weights. These dynamic weights are element-wise multiplied with the convolutional kernel weights to generate task-specific kernels (Task-specific weights). After the convolution operation with the task-specific kernels, the features undergo group normalization and activation functions to further enhance feature representation. The decoupled classification features (ClsFeat) and regression features (RegFeat) are then output, which are used for object classification and localization tasks, respectively.

In the classification branch, the features pass through the Confidence Calculation module to generate classification probabilities (ClsProb), which are used to adaptively adjust the classification feature weights, ensuring that high-confidence objects correspond to high localization quality.This module consists of a two-stage convolutional structure. First, the decoupled intermediate feature feat is passed through a 1 × 1 convolutional layer to compress the channel dimension and extract discriminative semantic information across channels. Subsequently, a 3 × 3 convolutional layer is applied to fuse local spatial contextual features. The output is then activated by ReLU and Sigmoid functions to generate a normalized probability map ClsProb ∈ [0, 1], which represents the confidence level of each pixel belonging to the foreground target.Based on this, the model performs an element-wise multiplication between the classification features (ClsFeat) and the classification probability (ClsProb) to construct an explicit task-alignment mechanism. This mechanism not only enhances the representation of high-confidence regions, but also effectively suppresses background noise and interference from low-confidence areas. As a result, it improves the consistency between classification scores and regression quality, thereby alleviating the conflict between classification and regression tasks.In the regression branch, the features first pass through the Spatial Offset Convolution module to generate the offsets (Offset) and masks (Mask), where the mask is constrained by a Sigmoid activation to limit the deformation range. Both are input to the dynamic deformable convolution (DyDCNv2) module, which adaptively adjusts the sampling locations and weights of the convolution kernels, achieving feature space alignment and receptive field optimization. To address the diverse shapes of mining-induced surface cracks (e.g., elongated, tortuous, or irregular shapes), DyDCNv2 dynamically adjusts the distribution of sampling points through learnable offsets, significantly improving the localization accuracy of irregular edges. In the final prediction phase, the regression features (RegFeat) are responsible for predicting the bounding box positions, while the classification features (ClsFeat) are responsible for predicting the object classes. To tackle the issue of extremely small crack targets being easily ignored in high-resolution mining-induced surface crack images (5472 × 3648 resolution), we introduce a Scale-Aware Module. Combined with the regression features (RegFeat), it enhances the model’s ability to adapt to cracks of different scales through multi-scale feature fusion and dynamic adjustments.

Small object feature enhancement pyramid (SOFEP)

Fig. 4

In object detection tasks, the detection performance of small objects is often limited on traditional P3, P4, and P5 detection layers. Traditional solutions typically enhance the detection capability for small objects by introducing the P2 detection layer. However, this approach often leads to issues such as a significant increase in computational cost and extended post-processing time. To address this problem, we propose an improved feature pyramid structure based on FPN-PAN (Feature Pyramid Network-Path Aggregation Network), called the Small Object Feature Enhancement Pyramid (SOFEP). As shown in Fig. 4, this structure retains the original backbone architecture while introducing two key modules, SPD-Conv and CSP-OmniKernel, to fully exploit and semantically fuse the small-object information from the P2 layer, thereby enhancing the overall feature representation capability.Unlike the conventional approach of adding the P2 detection layer, we process the P2 feature layer using the SPD-Conv module to generate features rich in small-object information and fuse them with the P3 layer. SPD-Conv consists of Space-to-Depth (SPD) layers and stride-less convolution layers, replacing traditional strided convolutions and pooling operations. This retains more fine-grained information, significantly improving the model’s performance in handling small-sized objects. As shown in Fig. 5, the case for scale = 2 is illustrated. To further enhance feature representation, we combine the idea of CSPNet46 with the Omni-Kernel network based on image inpainting47, and propose the CSP-OmniKernel module. The CSP structure divides the input features into two parts: one part undergoes feature enhancement through the Omni-Kernel module, while the other part is directly retained as a residual connection. Finally, the features processed by the Omni-Kernel module are concatenated with the original features, preserving both global and local information. The Omni-Kernel module performs multi-scale feature extraction through a multi-branch structure, using 1 × 3, 3 × 1, and 3 × 3 convolution kernels to capture the horizontal, vertical, and global features of cracks, respectively, while 1 × 1 convolutions enhance local detail information.

To further improve sensitivity to cracks, the Omni-Kernel module introduces a Frequency Domain Gating Mechanism (FGM). This mechanism uses Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to convert features into the frequency domain, where frequency-domain attention dynamically enhances the high-frequency edge information of cracks while suppressing background texture interference. The features are then reconstructed back into the spatial domain using Inverse Fast Fourier Transform (IFFT). Additionally, the module incorporates Spatial Channel Attention (SCA)48 and Frequency Channel Attention (FCA)49 mechanisms, which dynamically adjust feature weights in both spatial and channel dimensions, highlighting key crack areas and enhancing the model’s channel sensitivity to target features. Finally, multi-branch features are fused through residual connections, preventing gradient vanishing and accelerating model convergence, significantly improving the feature representation ability for small targets.

NWD regression loss function

To address the issues of gradient vanishing in zero-overlap scenarios and excessive sensitivity to small target position deviations in Intersection over Union (IoU)-based detection box similarity metrics, we introduce the NWD (Normalized Wasserstein Distance) regression loss function, which is more suitable for small-object detection. NWD models the bounding boxes as two-dimensional Gaussian distributions and calculates the normalized Wasserstein distance between the two distributions to assess their similarity. This approach better captures the subtle differences of small objects, thereby improving the model’s localization accuracy.

Evaluation metrics

In object detection tasks, model performance is typically evaluated using metrics such as precision, recall, and mean average precision (mAP). The model’s complexity is measured by the number of parameters and floating-point operations (FLOPs). True Positives (TPs) refer to cases where both the prediction and the actual label are positive. False Negatives (FNs) occur when the actual label is positive but the prediction is negative, while False Positives (FPs) occur when the actual label is negative but the prediction is positive. True Negatives (TNs) represent cases where both the prediction and the actual label are negative. The formulas for calculating precision and recall are as follows:1112

Intersection over Union (IoU) is a commonly used evaluation metric in object detection and image segmentation, used to measure the overlap between the predicted bounding box and the ground truth box. It is calculated by dividing the area of intersection between the predicted box and the ground truth box by the area of their union. The IoU value ranges from 0 to 1, with a higher value indicating a greater overlap between the predicted result and the ground truth. The formula for calculating IoU is as follows:13

The overall performance of a model is typically measured by Average Precision (AP), which represents the prediction accuracy above a specific IoU threshold. The calculation of AP involves precision and recall, and the AP value is the area under the precision-recall (P-R) curve. The mean average precision (mAP) is the average of the AP scores across all classes. mAP@0.5 refers to the average precision when the IoU threshold is 0.5, while mAP@0.5:0.95 refers to the average precision across multiple IoU thresholds ranging from 0.5 to 0.95. In addition, to evaluate the model’s real-time performance in practical application scenarios, Frames Per Second (FPS) was introduced as an evaluation metric. FPS indicates the number of image frames the model can process per second; a higher value implies faster detection speed and stronger real-time capability. This metric is particularly crucial for lightweight detection models deployed in resource-constrained environments, such as edge computing or mobile devices.

Conclusion

We designed an efficient and lightweight small object detection model based on the improved YOLO architecture, called YOLO-LSN. This model effectively addresses the challenges in detecting small cracks, complex crack shapes, significant scale differences, and the high background interference in UAV aerial mining-induced surface crack image detection. Specifically, we proposed two innovative plug-and-play modules (LDADH and SOFEP). The Lightweight Dynamic Alignment Detection Head (LDADH) module effectively tackles issues related to complex crack shapes and significant scale differences, enhancing the network’s ability in multi-scale feature fusion, feature space alignment, and dynamic adjustment of the receptive field. Ablation experiment results show that when this module is introduced alone, the parameter count decreases by 26.5% compared to the baseline model, meeting the lightweight requirement. The Small Object Feature Enhancement Pyramid (SOFEP) module uses SPD-Conv to extract fine-grained features from the P2 layer and fuses them with P3 layer features, while also integrating the CSP-OmniKernel module, which combines global perception, large kernel convolutions, and local branches. This improves the network’s ability in fine-grained feature capture and feature representation. To address the limitations of IoU (sensitivity to zero overlap, insensitivity to size deviation), we introduced the weighted combination of the NWD regression loss function and the IoU loss function, enabling more accurate capture of small target positions and improving the model’s localization accuracy. We constructed a mining-induced surface crack image dataset, and experimental results show that YOLO-LSN achieves a mAP50 of 0.544 on this dataset, a 12% improvement over the baseline, while reducing the parameter count by 17%, surpassing several mainstream models. Additionally, testing on the VisDrone2019 public dataset shows that the model achieves a mAP50 of 0.422, an 11.6% improvement over the baseline, which fully demonstrates the practical value of the proposed method in UAV aerial object detection and model lightweighting.

Despite achieving good results on the mining-induced surface crack image dataset, YOLO-LSN still has some limitations: Under extreme lighting conditions (e.g., strong shadows, reflections) or highly cluttered backgrounds (e.g., vegetation coverage), the detection accuracy of small target cracks may decrease, and further optimization of the model’s resistance to interference is needed.Although the model has been made lightweight, when deployed on low-power edge devices (e.g., UAV-mounted terminals), the processing frame rate for high-resolution images may not meet real-time monitoring requirements, necessitating a trade-off between accuracy and speed.

In the next step, we will explore multi-modal data fusion to enhance robustness in complex environments, while further compressing the model and accelerating inference. Additionally, we plan to construct a larger-scale cross-scenario crack dataset and incorporate self-supervised pre-training to enhance generalization. Based on our in-depth research and experimental validation, future work will continue to deepen the theoretical innovations and practical applications of small target crack detection in UAV aerial imagery, aiming to provide more efficient, accurate, and real-time intelligent detection solutions for fields such as mining safety monitoring and geological disaster early warning.

Publisher’s noteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

Soil erosion is a critical global issue, threatening the sustainability of natural resources and agricultural productivity. Accurate information on sediment yield and soil erosion risk within watersheds is essential for developing effective management strategies. This study aimed to estimate soil loss in the Upper Gilgel Abay catchment using the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT). The observed daily sediment data were utilized for the calibration and validation of the model outputs. Calibration and validation were performed for the periods 2002–2015 and 2016–2021, respectively. Sensitivity analysis identified the most influential parameters affecting soil loss estimates.

The model performance was quite satisfactory. The coefficient of determination (R2) was 0.69 for the calibration and 0.67 for the validation of sediment yield. Over the past 18 years, the Gilgel Abay catchment experienced approximately 1.5 billion tons of soil loss, with spatial analysis revealing soil loss rates of up to 53.88 t/ha/year, particularly in the upper catchment. The maximum and minimum annual sediment yields at the outlet of the catchment were 318, 233 tons, and 61,575 tons per year, respectively. On average 184,695 tons of soil leave the catchment annually. While the model provided an acceptable level of the average basin-wide soil loss, certain areas exhibited severe erosion. These findings underscore the urgent need for targeted soil conservation practices, such as terracing, reforestation, and sustainable land management, to mitigate soil degradation and enhance catchment sustainability.

IntroductionAccording to the Global Soil Partnership hosted by FAO, arable land loses 75 billion tons of soil each year, which is equal to a USD 400 billion loss in the economy1. Approximately 36 billion tons of soil is lost worldwide each year, as per the latest estimates2. The rate of soil erosion in the world is between 12 and 15 t ha-1 y-13. It shows that the removal of the top layer 0.96 to 1.2 mm annually, resulting in losses of between US$64 and US$80 billion4. Soil erosion accelerates the occurrence of land degradation in tropical regions such as the Ethiopian highlands. It has a negative consequence for food security, agricultural productivity and sustainable management of natural resources5,6.

Ethiopia has extremely high rates of soil erosion, with the highlands losing roughly 3.5 billion tons of soil per year, 1.5 billion of which depart the nation through its rivers. Ethiopia’s environmental issue is grave and ongoing due to soil erosion. Due to Ethiopia’s uneven topography, soil erosion is a major environmental problem that has a substantial effect on agricultural productivity and the long-term viability of those areas7,8. The critical nature of this problem has been revealed by recent investigations. For instance, a synthesis of modeling and plot-level research by Tadesse et al.9 demonstrated that assessments of soil erosion in Ethiopia have attracted a lot of interest in the past 40 years. The study underscored the importance of boosting watershed and plot-level monitoring, especially in arid and semi-arid regions. Furthermore, the lower Baro watershed’s shifting land cover a reduction in wetlands, shrubland, rangeland, and forest land, and an increase in built-up regions, agricultural land, and water bodies have had a substantial impact on hydrological variables10.

Sedimentation in downstream or sediment deposition in the reservoirs is a serious off-site impact of soil erosion as it shortens the reservoir’s design life and reduces the dams’ sustainability11. Sediments are frequently seen as an unfavorable but unavoidable side effect of water storage. Reservoir sedimentation results in an annual loss of 2% of the intended storage volume12. In addition to affecting the quality of water bodies, the erosion of the catchments’ most fertile soils reduces their capacity to hold water through the sedimentation process13.

Water-induced soil erosion continues to be the primary driver of land degradation, making it the most significant environmental issue in the world. Additionally, a lack of appropriate erosion prevention measures and an increase in farming activities are major contributors to this issue14,15. To estimate runoff-induced soil erosion, soil erosion models are frequently used worldwide, such as the Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE) and its updated version Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE), the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT), the European Soil Erosion Model (Euro SEM) the Water Erosion Prediction Project (WEPP)7. The updated version of the Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE) has limitations, including the result obtained using this model mainly depending on the input data given by the expert during processing, which could be affected by personal bias and error16. Accelerated erosion via sheet and rill erosion results in a deposition in lake Tana17. Globally, the SWAT model has been effectively used for determining the extent to which Soil and Water Conservation (SWC) methods reduce runoff, reduce soil erosion, and increase groundwater recharge18. The SWAT model effectively simulates hydrological and sediment processes allowing for the identification of erosion hotspots and application of effective conservation measures19. Studies conducted in the Hombole, Weyb and Gidabo, watersheds have validated SWAT’s performance in quantifying soil erosion and sediment yield20,21. In Ethiopia, research combining the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT) with geospatial technologies in various watersheds has emphasized the critical role of vegetation covers and proper land-use management in reducing soil erosion22. According to Gebresamuel et al.23, these models have been used in studies carried out in similar watersheds, like the Chamo basin in Southern Ethiopia. Furthermore, a study by Leta et al.24 utilized the SWAT model to estimate sediment yield and soil erosion in the Nashe watershed, Ethiopia. This research identified key areas contributing to sediment and assessed the total amount of soil loss in the watershed. In this case, identifying the priority locations for intervention and assessing the effectiveness of soil conservation measures have been made possible by the application of the SWAT model.

The upper Gilgel Abay catchment faces a land degradation problem with soil erosion from upstream and subsequent sedimentation in the downstream area. Due to its complicated terrain, the upper Gilgel Abay catchment is particularly vulnerable to soil erosion, which could be exacerbated by several factors such as high rates of wind and water erosion, overgrazing, high rainfall variability, high rainfall intensity, and heavy rainfall25. Even though this issue is critical, prior research has mostly concentrated on general evaluations of soil erosion in the area, paying little thought to the regional variations in erosion risk and sedimentation mechanisms. Prior research has primarily used empirical models to conduct generalized assessments of soil erosion. For instance, Bewket and Teferi26 used remote sensing data to perform a qualitative assessment of land degradation based on changes in land use and land cover, while Gelagay and Minale27 used the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE) combined with GIS and satellite imagery to estimate annual soil loss around Koga watershed. Despite their value, these studies frequently lack spatially explicit modeling of the dynamics of sediment yield and routing, particularly at the catchment outlet. As a result, the accurate determination of the risk of soil erosion and the amount of sediment at the outlet is essential for sustainable watershed management. Estimation of soil loss effectively and conveniently, evaluating the risk of soil erosion, and applying conservation measures become an urgent task. This study attempts to fill this gap by using high-resolution remote sensing data and the SWAT model to determine the risk of soil erosion, calculate the amount of sediment deposited at the outlet, and locate the Upper Gilgel Abay catchment’s priority areas for conservation.

Materials and methods

Study area description

The upper Gilgel Abay catchment, which corresponds to the gauged portion of the Gilgel Abay river basin, is one of the major tributaries of Ethiopia’s lake Tana basin. It encompasses a total area of 163,557.31 ha. It is located at 10° 56′ 53″ to 11° 21′ 58″N latitudes and 36° 49′ 29″ to 37° 23′ 34″E longitudes17,28 (Fig. 1).

The southern and southeastern regions of the catchment consist of highlands with mountain ranges, whereas the northern edge, despite being at a high altitude, is relatively flat compared to the rest of the area29. The elevation varies from 1883 m a.s.l. to 3511 m a.s.l. The mean annual precipitation in the Upper Gilgel Abay catchment is approximately 1400 mm and the mean daily minimum and maximum temperatures range between 15 °C and 23 °C on average17,30. Andosols, Luvisols, and Vertisols are the three main soil orders in the catchment31.

The natural vegetation in the Upper Gilgel Abay catchment is represented by Cordia africana, Juniperus procera, Croton macrostachyus, Rumex nervosus Vahl, Carissa spinarum, Dodonaea angustifolia, Olea europaea, and Rosa abyssinica Lindley32. Cropland dominates the Gilgel Abay catchment, with a few scattered forests and forested peaks. Grassland, marshes, and woodland with regular areas of shrubs and eucalyptus forests are the predominant land cover types, aside from cultivated fields28.

The SWAT model

SWAT is a hydrological model developed by the USDA to predict how different land management practices will affect agricultural productivity33. The model utilizes spatial data from geospatial technologies, incorporating an integrated physical framework that considers different factors such as climate, topography, soil properties and land use and management practices34. The SWAT model, selected for its flexibility and strong performance in hydrological studies, has been widely utilized to simulate runoff, evaluate the effects of climate and land-use changes, and aid in water resource management across various environmental and agro-climatic settings35. During modeling, the catchment was separated into several sub-catchments to reduce the running time and help get accurate results36. Soil erosion and sediment yield was estimated using a modified version of the universal soil loss equation (MUSLE). Modified Universal Soil Loss Equation (MUSLE) predict sediment yield as a function of runoff factor on a given day38. MUSLE is applied in SWAT by assuming a basic hydrograph shape to estimate daily runoff volume and peak flow rate within each sub-watershed, which is then used to predict changes in runoff erosive energy. SWAT calculates sediment yield as total sediment load and as fractions of sand, silt, and clay for each sub-watershed Eq. (2)39.2

Where A represents the sediment yield (metric tons), Qsurf the surface runoff (mm per hectare), qpeak the peak rate of runoff (m3/s), Ahru the hydrologic response unit area (hectares), K the soil erodibility factor, C the cover and management factor, P the support practice factor, LS the slope length and steepness factor, and Cfrg the coarse fragment40.

The SWAT model was selected as an effective model for forecasting soil erosion and sediment yield for the following reasons41. SWAT considers the entire water system of the catchment while RUSLE focuses on estimating soil erosion on individual plots. It considers the spatial variability of the physio-chemical properties of the soil and the land use activities practiced in the area allowing for a comprehensive analysis of water resources and sediment yield. It considers the complexity of the catchment and relies on the detailed knowledge of climate data, soil properties as well as vegetation cover in the catchment. It is computationally efficient, easily accessible and unrestricted42. SWAT is used in a wide range of Ethiopian scenarios (suitable and yielded positive results)33.

SWAT model input data and sources

The catchment boundary and catchment slope were created using SRTM 1 Arc-Second Global DEM (30 m) obtained from the USGS website (Table 1). The SRTM 1 Arc-Second Global DEM is a crucial input for the SWAT model, providing essential information about the topography of the watershed, including stream network delineation, watershed boundary definition, slope, and flow direction. Daily climatic data were obtained from the National Meteorological Institute of Ethiopia. Soil data were obtained from the ISRIC World Soil Information database and used to prepare a soil map of the catchment. World imagery from 2020 with a 1.19 m resolution, accessed through ArcGIS Pro, was used to prepare a land use map of the area. Measured hydrological data were obtained from the Ministry of Water and Energy, Ethiopia (MoWE).

Weather

One of the major inputs used by the SWAT Model is climate data. The daily climatic data required by SWAT for simulation were obtained from the National Meteorological Institute of Ethiopia. The climatic data were taken from four meteorological stations, including Sekela, Durbet, Gilgel Abay and Adis Alem stations. Each station provided data on precipitation, as well as maximum and minimum temperatures, as shown in Table 2. The record period spans from January 2001 to December 2021, except for the Sekela station, which covers 2001–2018, with missing data from 2019 to 2021 filled using CHIRPS. Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (CHIRPS) is a high-resolution rainfall dataset developed by the Climate Hazards Group at the University of California, Santa Barbara. It integrates ground-based station data with satellite imagery to generate reliable precipitation estimates. CHIRPS offers quasi-global coverage (50°S–50°N) from 1981 to the present, with a spatial resolution of 0.05° (~ 5 km) and temporal resolutions of daily, pentadal, and monthly. It is particularly useful in regions with limited ground data and is freely available at (https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirps). According to Bennett43, The CHIRPS dataset, derived from rain gauge measurements and satellite observations, demonstrated the highest performance among the open-access precipitation products reviewed, as evaluated using scatterplots and correlation coefficients. This included comparisons with products such as CFSR and ERA5. CHIRPS was also employed to address missing values in some climatic variables at individual stations. Before integration into the model, the weather data underwent quality control procedures, including the detection of missing or inconsistent values. In cases of data gaps, CHIRPS precipitation data was specifically employed to fill missing records for individual stations, ensuring the continuity and reliability of the weather dataset for the simulation. The final step in handling weather data involved formatting all climate datasets into SWAT-compatible input files (i.e., text files).

Soil data including soil physio-chemical properties is also one of the key inputs of the SWAT model. Five significant soil groups were found in the catchment using the FAO/UNESCO - ISRIC categorization (Fig. 2). A soil lookup table with soil code and soil name was prepared to relate the map with the model.

Land use

The SWAT model heavily depends on land use as an input, which has significant effects on the definition and behavior of hydrological response units (HRUs). Land use land cover classification was conducted using ArcGIS Pro. World imagery of 2020 with 1.19 m resolution was extracted using the watershed boundary as a mask layer. Six land use classes and a new schema were generated using the extracted imagery under the imagery tab in the ArcGIS Pro training sample manager. Schema and training sample points were saved. After saving the classification schema and training points, the extracted imagery was selected. Under the imagery tab in the classification tools, the ‘Classify Images’ option was used, and the Maximum Likelihood Classification algorithm was applied to classify the image. The training samples were added, and the classification was performed by specifying the output directory21. After classifying the image small errors in the classification results were edited to individual features or objects by creating a polygon on the classified image and replacing the first land use type with the new land use types using a reclassifier in the classification tool (Fig. 3). After the accurate land use classification, a lookup table was prepared for each land use and land cover type having four-letter codes recommended by SWAT to make the land use name compatible with the model. Slope

The slope parameter used in this study was derived from a SRTM 1 Arc-Second Global DEM using ArcGIS software. Specifically, the “Slope” tool available under the Spatial Analyst extension was employed to compute the slope within the study area. The resulting slope raster was subsequently utilized as one of the key input layers for the soil erosion and sediment yield modeling. The slope classes were determined based on commonly accepted terrain classification standards used in land evaluation and watershed management, following Morgan44. The catchment was divided into five slope classes: 0–5% (flat), 5–15% (smooth to undulating), 15–30% (steep/undulating), 30–40% (moderately steep), and > 40% (steep slopes). This classification aligns with categorizations applied in hydrological models and erosion studies for hilly and mountainous regions, ensuring a structured approach to terrain assessment (Fig. 4).

The daily streamflow data, provided by the Ministry of Water and Energy, Ethiopia, covered the period from 2002 to 2021.
